characters: THE TAPE--THE U.S. ATTORNEY'S OFFICE TODAY ANNOUNCED
STOCK BROKER BUD FOX, FOR CONSPIRACY TO COMMIT SECURITIES
CRIMINAL CHARGES AGAINST CORPORATE RAIDER GORDON GEKKO AN
FRAUD, TAX EVASION, VIOLATIONS OF SECURITY ACTS, AND MAIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FADE IN. THE STREET. The most famous third of a mile in t world. Towering landmark structures nearly blot out the dreary grey flannel sky. The morning rush hour crowds swa through the dark, narrow streets like mice in a maze, all pursuit of one thing: MONEY... CREDITS RUN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the ROAR of the trains pulling out of the station Blurred faces, bodies, suits, hats, attache cases float i view pressed like sardines against the sides of a door wh now open, releasing an outward velocity of anger and gree one of them BUD FOX.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bubbling mass charges up the stairs. Steam rises from grating, shapes merging into the crowd. Past the HOMELESS VETS, the insane BAG LADY with 12 cats and 20 shopping ba huddled in the corner of Trinity Church... Bud the Fox straggling behind, in a crumpled raincoat, ti askew, young, very young, his bleary face buried in a Wal Street Journal, folded, 'subway style', as he crosses the street against the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why Fox? Why didn't you buy... schmuck? A car honks, swerving past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavernous modern lobby. Bodies cramming into elevators. B stuffing the newspaper into his coat, jams in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blank faces stare ahead, each lost in private thoughts, B again mouthing the thought, "stupid schmuck", his eyes catching a blond executive who quickly flicks her eyes aw Paranoia in the elevator. We quickly cut into private liv

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... he'll sue me, could be for 5-6 million, and he'll get a million, the house, they'll impound my paychecks...damn, damn, why did I sign that contract?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... gotta get Lola in the sack man, take her to the Garden for the Terrells, Jimmy give me the tickets for 12 bucks, I pull the midnight shift, I could do 60 bucks... wow, check those legs out... His eyes on the same blonde exec who looks away, self- conscious about her legs. The elevator stops at a floor, discards only one person. The doors close a little too sl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... jerk... (shifts her thoughts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: call Hanratty. The decimal points on the code are uncalibrated. Hoskins. The signatures on the bank draft. Boyle, that bitch...insurance...tax form. Shit, talk to Kahn. (recalling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Hanratty, Hoskins, Bank, Boyle and Kahn... H2B2K - shoot, insurance and theatre tix...H2B2K,I,T -- and the cleaners! repeat... Catching the eyes of Bud Fox once again wandering to her. Camera moving to Bud who looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...sorry, what a fox... funny, the most beautiful girls in the world are always on the street or in elevators, never get to talk to them, shy ... my looks, never had confidence in them ... overcompensating work syndrome... prove your worth with money... 'cept I'm not making any money... (pause, the elevator at another floor, slow)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... wonder what all these people are thinking about. Camera moving slowly again over the eyes. The silence of individual tension reigns over all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Screw him! I'll destroy that sonufabitch... he thinks he can break a contract with me he's got something to learn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...9:15!... he'll kill me this time, he will really kill me... oh come on elevator!... why do you stop on every floor... As the elevator stops again to disgorge two people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pissed now at the elevator)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... come on man, time is money man... One floor here I could do eleven blocks...

dialogues.speaker: H2B2K,I,T,CL,P,O,T2...
dialogues.text: (pause, she looks like she forgot something)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...goddamn elevators!...people, too many goddamn people in this world! The elevator finally comes to a slow stop... They wait, plead, beg, screech with the eyes. The door at last opens. None of them acknowledging each other, they all stampede out the door with an audible gas of release, a collective sign akin to making it to a urin after a punishing wait... The elevator tension is over, but the killer grind contin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Credits continue to run. Bud moves past the functional reception area, past CAROLYN, a cheerful young black girl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doing Buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great Carolyn, doing any better would be a sin... He slips off his overcoat, flicks some lint off his Paul Stuart $500 suit, and enters the main trading room. Brokers mill by their desks, gulping coffee, scanning the papers, the quotrons. The digital clock by the big board counter clicks to 9:26 am -- four minutes until the marke opens. You can smell the hunger. Bud takes a deep breath, tosses the newspaper away and struts into the office -- fuck it -- it's a new day. MOVING past DAN STEEPLES, a flush-faced old-timer, a blue and white Yale tie, with a carnation in his lapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Dan. What's looking good today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I know I wouldn't be in this business. Get out while you're young, kid. I came here one day, I sat down, and look at me now. Past CHARLIE CUSHING, on the phone, a handsome chunk of m with rugged good looks and Ivy League mannerisms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...hey Chuckie, how's the woman- slayer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...still looking for the right 18 year old wife, how you doing, pal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...if I had your looks, better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (used to it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...takes years of genetics, pal, and a Yale education... and the right tailor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...not that you learned anything, Chunk. Bud reaches his trading desk, whips open his briefcase an pulls out a computer print-out of last night's homework.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta feeling we're going to make a killing today, Marv.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, where's your machine gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joke about it. I was up all night charting these stocks. You want to see this or what? His associate, MARVIN, a manicky wise-guy, swivels over h chair from a nearby desk. He gives the charts a quick rea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scowling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks bearish to me, buddy. You got it all upside down. (confidential)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm giving this to you and you alone, 'cause I feel sorry for you. Take the Knicks against the Bullets, and my pick of the day -- Duke to beat the spread against Wake Forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Marv, with that I might be able to qualify for welfare. LOU MANNHEIM, strolls in, a dignified looking older broke in his late 60's, wearing an old brown brim hat with butt down white shirt, narrow tie, very much a picture from another era... a kind humor in his eyes... but obviously ailing in the legs and breath department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (friendly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a look in your eye, Mr. Mannheim... You got something for the small fry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, can't make a buck in this market, country's going to hell faster than when that sonofabitch Roosevelt was around... too much cheap money sloshing around the world. The biggest mistake we ever made was letting Nixon get off the gold standard. Putney Drug--you boys might want to have a look at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take 5 years for that company to turn around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but they got a good new drug. Stick to the fundamentals, that's how IBM and Hilton were built...good things sometimes take time. The stentorian voice of OFFICE MANAGER HIERONYMUS LYNCH booms over the intercom. We see him peering from behind the glass partition in hit office; tall, balding with a perpetual worried look on hi face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attention. Please. Office Production is down ten percent this week. I recommend that you all go through your clients' investments for any portfolio adjustments. And don't forget -- double commissions today on our 'A' or better bond funds. (looking in Bud and Marv's direction)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Especially you rookies. Also, remember, the sales contest ends tomorrow. Bud and Marvin roll their eyes. The digital clock flashes 9:30. The CREDITS close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they're off and running! The room rises to a subtle but new energy level with the clatter of the ticker, speakers, teletype machines, newsprinters' Dow Jones and Reuters, phones ringing off t hook. Brokers are shouting orders, running for tickets, dodging each other; it's a controlled riot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's a hot lead... Have I got one for you.... sell ... dump it all!! ... 500 at an eighth, an eighth!... July fifties. April thirties...how bout those Decembers? You see where they're going? ... Morgan is selling a billion one at the close. Yeah. That's right, they're selling all over the place... we're still long on the treasuries -- $110 million. What about the Japs? ...Where am I? (confused at all the phone lights)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta lot of lights here! Let's pick 'em up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, take 50 Gulf, with a 3/8 top, forget the hundred. What about Delroy? I can go long at 23, let's go long...Conwest Air -- let me check it... He looks up at the TICKER... stock quotes whizzing by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up an eighth. How many you want? It's on the floor. He writes the order up. A shot of CHARLIE CUSHING yawning as he half-listens to h customer, resting the phone on his kneecaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CLOCK... It's 2.30 p.m. We hear the relentless clatte of the board ticker, and the drone of disembodied voices, blarihg market information out of squawk boxes. Bud's desk is now cluttered with order tickets, literatur crumpled notes, beverage cups and a half-eaten sandwich. He's on the phone and from the look on his face, the call on the other end is breaking his balls. Marvin paces past making a dramatic phone pitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Beltzer has to have his information this minute! It concerns his future! Bud waves Marvin away, answers his caller, trying to keep cool, worried how as he sees Lynch, the office manager, coming over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Howard, I thought you were a gentleman. Sure it's gone down a little bit, but you got the tip from your printer, I didn't... Yeah you did. That's what you said. (heated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't tell you to buy it, why would I tell you to sell it? (screaming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I can't give it back! Give it back to who? You own it! (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's out right now. As he looks up and winks at Lynch, standing over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cupping the receiver)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... That's what you told us to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me that phone. (takes receiver)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, this is the manager. What seems to be the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into his phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?... Well, how was I to know you were in surgery? What am I Marvin the mind reader here? Bud whispers, tensely. Lynch listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, sir. I'll discuss this with the broker and I'll get back to you. You're welcome. Lynce hangs up and glares at Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'm closing out this account. If he doesn't pay for it tomorrow, you pay for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Lynch, I swear to you, he's lying!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox, you're making more problems than you are sales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you're being fair, sir. You assigned me this guy, and you know he's got a history...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody has to pay for that error. And it's not me. Lynch walks off. Bud does some quick calculations in his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reappearing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy, buddy, buddy; little trouble, huh, today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (devastated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard the Jerk reneged on me. I've got to cover his loss to the tune of about seven grand! I'm tapped out man, American Express got a hit man looking for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, things could be worse. It could've been my money. Let me help you out, rookie. He takes out his wallet and loans Bud a hundred bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks Marv, I'll make it good to you. (fervently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what my dream is? One day to be on the other end of that phone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just put me on the institutional side of the room where the real cheesecake is. You forgetting something? Marvin points up at the clock. Bud looks up... it's 2:40. Bud quickly composes himself. He picks up the phone, dial purposefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy, buddy, when ya gonna realize it's big game hunters that bag the elephants, not retail brokers. I heard this story about Gekko... he was on the phone 30 seconds after the Challenger blew up selling NASA stocks short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Natalie -- guess who? That's right, and you know everyday I say to myself, today could be the day... So what do you say... will you marry me? Then please can you get me through to Mr. Gekko?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coaching)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It concerns his future!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course he's busy, and so am I. Five minutes. That's all I'm asking. I know that if he could only hear what I have to say... it would change his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NATALIE, a classy attractive Englishwoman is on the phone with Bud, somewhat amused by his manner. She is the perso secretary to multimillionaire, Wall Street trader and raider, Gordon Gekko. His windows look out on a panoramic view of the city and East River.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Fox, I've told you before, I'm sure you're a good broker, but our traders talk to the brokers, Mr. Gekko only deals with investment bankers. Yes, I shall give him your message ... As they're speaking, another SECRETARY leads two well-hee JAPANESE BUSINESSMEN past her desk. As she opens the door the inner office and ushers them inside, we catch a glimp of a figure, pacing back and forth, talking animatedly on the phone by the huge corner window. HE IS GORDON GEKKO. hear a deafening ROAR as we:

dialogues.speaker: TWILIGHT
dialogues.text: In the background, a 747 ascends into the night sky, climbing over the roof tops of weathered brick tract hous Bud, coat collar pulled up against the wind, crosses the street, entering a neighborhood bar. We see an old maroon Honda behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dimly-lit, noisy, blue-collar airline bar. Machinists and mechanics still in their overalls at the bar, drinking, watching ESPN FIGHT NIGHT, on TV. Bud searches the crowd. group of middle-aged men wave him over, BLUESTAR AIRLINES insignias on the pockets... CHARLIE DENT, a rugged, chain smoking ex-Marine Sergeant, and DOMINICK AMATO, a big str Italian greet Buddy as he comes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy boy, how ya doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great Charlie, any better it'd be a sin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slapping Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear all you guys on Wall Street are millionaires, when you gonna make us rich?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta open an account to win the lottery, Dominick. Give me 15,000, you'll have a condo in Florida next Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... sure and we'll own the airline. If he makes anybody rich, let him make himself rich, so's he can pay off his school loans. As he signs an unemployment insurance form for one of his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... nice to see you in such a good mood Dad, what'd Mom do, give you fish for dinner? ... You're smoking too much, how many times do you gotta go to the hospital to ... Carl, inhaling his cigarette, grimaces formidably, terminating the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...leave me alone willya. Only thing makes me feel good anymore. Spaghetti. She makes lousy spaghetti...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's called pasta now Dad, spaghetti's out of date. Bud sitting down next to him, pats him around the shoulde Dad, a sarcastic and gruff edge to him, makes a faint smi He has a genuine affection and pride in his somewhat glamorous son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... so am I. Whaddaya want, a beer? (to waitress)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Billie, bring another for the kid, he looks good, doesn't he? Dominick and Charlie go off. A pause. Father and son sizi each other up with a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... looks like you grown another inch... but you don't look so hot, getting bags under your eyes, starting to look old like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, I had a tough day. Some jerk D.K'd me and I gotta cover his loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak English will ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D.K. -- didn't know -- who I was when the options he bought took a bath. He reneged on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods, satisfied)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you not to go into that racket. You could've been a doctor or a lawyer,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coulda been a contender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: you coulda stayed at Bluestar and been a supervisor in instead of going customer relations by now, 'stead of going off and bein' a salesman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an old story between them)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look Dad, I'm not a salesman. How many times I gotta tell you I'm an account executive, and pretty soon I'm going to the investment banking side of the firm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get on the phone and ask strangers for their money, right? You're a salesman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BUD (ticked)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, it takes time. You gotta build a customer list. I'm doing it. I could make more money in one year as a broker than five years at the airline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it, you get a scholarship to NYU, you get 35,000 the first year, and 50 last year, where the hell is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50 K don't get you to first base in the Big Apple, Dad, not any more. I pay 40% in taxes, I got a rent of 15,000, I got school loans, car loans, food, park my car costs me 3 bills a month, I need good suits, that's $500 a pop, shoes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So come home and live rent free, 'stead of that cockroach palace you live in. $50,000 Jesus Christ, the world is off its rocker. I made $37,000 last year and you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Queens, Dad and a 5% mortgage and you rent the top room--I gotta live in Manhattan to be a player, Dad. There's no nobility in poverty anymore, y'know. One day you're going to be proud of me, you'll see... (hurting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sees it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's yourself you've got to be proud of, Huckleberry, how much ya need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you spare three hundred? Pay you back next month, promise. Dad reaches into his pocket, looks at his cash. It hurts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Got a 100 on me, you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in here Dad... please. Later. Dad shrugs, puts it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... it adds up Buddy, 300 here, 200 there. Your brother never... (cuts off when he sees Buddy's face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...well, I always said money is something you need in case you don't die tomorrow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (changes subject)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Mom? Another man comes over with a bandage around his head and compensation form for Carl to sign. ("Hey, chief").

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with affection)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...same, pain in the ass, god bless her, talks too much... gonna take her to Florida next month... west coast, near Tampa, like to get out for good, but can't afford it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Work okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lights another cigarette, grimaces)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...this drug testing is driving my guys nuts. I got flagged for my blood pressure pills. The only good news is, we just met with the comptroller over some union stuff...'member that crash last summer? and the investigation? Well, the FAA is gonna rule it was a manufacturing flaw in the door latch mechanism. I kept telling 'em it wasn't maintenance, it was those goddamn greedy manufacturers out in Cincinnati. And I was right. He gives the signed form back to the injured man. (Carl: "Okay, Frank")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn right, it gets us out from under suspension. We'll get those new routes to Pittsburgh and Boston and the equipment we need. We're gonna compete with the big boys now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (boasts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey to Bluestar, as your broker all I can advise is hold on to that stock Dad... They drink. Bud reflects a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure about this FAA announcement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FAA announcement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I'm sure. Buddy, you got that mischievous look in your eyes. You used to smile just like that when you were a baby sleeping, just like that. Bud's mind racing elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cramped studio facing an air shaft with bars on the win Moving across to the sound of the radio alarm going off a the glib tones of a rock D.J. announcing the Met's latest streak ... The walls are papered with stock analyses and graphs, print out pages strewn across the floor. No other semblance of a personal life except clothes haphazardly tossed, Barron's and Fortune magazines. A GIRL's back is we see, sleeping naked on the bed. Close on Bud's IBM computer -- his appointment calendar. focusing on an underlined notation: G.G.'s BIRTHDAY. Bud stares at the clock: 4 a.m. He picks up a prospectus a chemical company, starts reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud, crossing lower Broadway, enters a magnificent toweri glass structure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NATALIE, Gekko's British secretary, is completing shortha notes as the intercom buzzes. A logo for "GEKKO & CO. behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I have a delivery here for Mr. Gekko. It's a personal item and the gentleman says you have to sign for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...all right, send him in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud, somewhat nervous, is led down an impressive hallway hung with expensive modern art... past a huge Calder mobi and a pool of some 15 traders on phones, quotron terminal and keyboards... into Natalie's outer office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Natalie, you recognize the voice? I'll give you a hint, you're thinking seriously about marrying me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (recognizing the voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And you're even lovelier than I pictured. I brought a birthday present for Mr. Gekko.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First of all, Mr. Fox, you can't just come barging in here. And what makes you think it's his birthday? Bud takes out an old crumpled Fortune magazine cover of Gordon Gekko, entitled "Gekko the Great!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in the bible, see. You better go buy him a present. Please, Natalie. Let me give him the gift; Cuban cigars--Davidoff, his favorite and hard to get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay here, I'll see what I can do. She takes the gift and enters Gekko's office. Bud paces nervously. Natalie re-appears, stern, but a note of compromise in her voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud on the courtesy phone, hangs up, looks nervously at h watch. Almost 12. He's lost some two hours of business. Natalie suddenly comes out, without a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five minutes... Bud brightens, pumping himself in the mirror, muttering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Natalie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... life all comes down to a few moments, and this is one of 'em... He follows Natalie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Furnishings in hypermodern gray and black lacquer, Modern Art ranging from black field paintings by Ad Reinhardt to the smashed dishes of Julian Schnabel. Nautilus equipment hi-tech gadgets are in evidence, including a splendid How Miller World Time Clock, and a world map... Three of Gekko's people, young MBA's dressed for success, are scattered about the room, on phones, calculators, com in and out. GORDON GEKKO aka Gekko the Great as the media calls him, dressed in a custom English suit, paces on the phone with the restlessness of a caged tiger, a 50-foot extension co attached to his blinking 130 line silver-plated telephone On his ears is a headset. He is carrying on overlapping conversations with a myriad bankers, partners and lawyers; pausing to issue commands his aides while keeping his eye on the stock prides spitt across a bank of quotron monitors, carrying everything fr New York Exchanges to London, commodities, gold, and currency values. A second Secretary and sometimes Natalie exit and enter with various messages written on a piece o paper, indicating a waiting party on the phone. Gekko oft shakes his head "no".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... what the hell is going on? I just saw 200,000 shares move, are we part of it, we better be, pal, or I'm gonna eat your lunch for you... get on 1. (switches lines)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, love it at forty. It's an insult at fifty. Their analysts don't know preferred stock from livestock... (a beat, mischievous smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wait for it to head south, then we'll raise the sperm count on the deal... right. Get back to me.... (to Alex, an aide listening an the other line)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the kid that's called me 59 days in a row. Wants to be a player (to Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There oughta be a picture of you in the dictionary under persistence. (back to phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Jerry, I'm looking for negative control, no more than 30 to 35%, just enouqh to block anybody else's merger plans and find out from the inside if the books are cooked. If it looks as good as on paper, we're in the kill zone. We lock and load pal...get on 3. ALEX DE BETANCOURT, a tall handsome Frenchman, jots a not and follows Gordon over to line 3. Gekko's dark intent ey fixing briefly on Bud who stands waiting in the corner. H motions him to sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (new line)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Billy, who's your buyer?... No, not interested. (eyes an Quotron, to Ollie, a trader)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ollie, start calling a the institutions, start with Marx at Janson Mutual, then Reardon. Get me that California retirement money, baby! And we're on our way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it, G.G. OLLIE, a gigantic 200 pound man wearing pink suspenders, rises and walks to another phone, past Bud...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back on line with Billy, listening)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... check the arbs for MacDonald's. Yeah, I'm having a Mac attack. 20,000 shares. For about 30 minutes. Lunch? Are you joking -- lunch is for wimps. Get back to me... (to Alex)

Bud's eyes on the framed "tombstones" from the Wall Stree Journal commemorating Gekko's successful deals; they hang like scalps from the walls. Gekko's eyes drifting to Bud, friendly easy smile for a flick of an instant, he has genuine charm in his manner and though ultrafast verbally projects calm and confidence at the center. A man who obviously loves what he does, to some small degree is flashing his stuff for the outsider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (line 4)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look Harold, they're vulnerable, alright, but we don't want 'em to think they're under accumulation. Go slow. Call Geneva and the Bahamas for me, will ya? We feint towards it but we wait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about tipping off Yurovich?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimaces)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I ever need surgery, get me the heart of an arb like Yurovich, it's never been used...Happy Holideals Harold... Hangs up, eyes to Bud. His headset comes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do Mr. Gekko. I'm Bud Fox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you say. Nice to meet you; hope you're intelligent. Like these, how'd you get these? (indicating cigars)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tries a smile, awkward)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...got a connection at the airport. Gekko notes the answer, wrapping the cuff of a state-of-t art, automatic blood pressure monitor around his arm and starts pumping it up. His aides continue on the phones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what s on your mind kimosabe? Why am I listening to you? Got to monitor my blood pressure, so whatever you do, don't upset me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (demonstrating it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Within 45 seconds, a microprocessor computes your systolic and diastolic pressure. Has an LCD readout, and it's cost effective -- less than one visit to the doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to let you know Mr. Gekko I read all about you at NYU Business, and I think you're an incredible genius and I've always dreamed of only one thing -- to do business with a man like you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles, impatient with the speech)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what firm you with, pal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson, Steinem...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...going places, good junk bond department, you got the financing on that Syndicam deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Yeah, and we're working on some other interesting stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fishing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...A cosmetics company by any chance? What are you, the 12th man on the deal team? The last to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't tell you that, Mr. Gekko.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So whatta you got for me, sport? Why are you here? Bud opens his attache case and rifles out a handful of briefs. Gekko noting the blood pressure reading and takin the cuff off his arm. Ollie, the big trader, ambles back says something to the third aide, a young intelligent- looking woman SUSAN TURNER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chart break-out on this one here...uh Whitewood-Young Industries...low P.E. Explosive earnings. 30% discount from book. Great cash flow. Coupla 5% holders. Strong management.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a dog, what else you got, sport, besides connections at the airport?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Stevenson in San Fransisco. Gekko takes the call, cutting Bud off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He respond to the offer? What? What the hell's Cromwell doing giving lecture tours when his company's losing 60 million a quarter? I guess he's giving lectures on how to lose money...if this guy opened a funeral parlor, no one would die, this turkey's totally brain dead...Well Christmas is over and business is business. (simultaneous to Ollie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep buying. Dilute the sonofabitch. Ollie I want every orifice in his body flowing red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs, on the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's flowing, Gordo. Piece of cake. Gekko hanging up and buzzing an aide. Throws out an aside Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...doesn't look like it but the best trader on the street... (to Susan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue get the LBO analysis on Teldar Paper and bring it here...what else? Bud shifting, uncomfortable as Gekko finally swivels his attention back to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming right back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tarafly...Analysts don't like it. I do. The breakup value is twice the market price. The deal finances itself. Sell off two divisions, keep... Aiex, knowing the stock, sneers, shares a look with Gekko who looks up at Bud with the first sign of interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad for a quant, but a dog with different fleas. (checks his hi-tech watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, tell me something I don't know. It's my birthday, pal, surprise me... As he opens a birthday card and feeds it into the SHREDDE that sits next to his desk over the waste basket. The sou it makes is soft and menacing. Buddy knows its fourth dow and long, Gekko's attention is shifting to the quotron. I frustration, Bud blurts it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bluestar Airlines. The camera moves on him now, sudden, more intense, in a sense trapping him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...rings a bell somewhere. So what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A comer. 80 medium-body jets. 300 pilots, flies northeast, Canada, some Florida and Caribbean routes... great slots in major cities...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...don't like airlines, lousy unions...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a crash last year. They just got a favorable ruling on a lawsuit. Even the plaintiffs don't know. Gekko looks up, remotely interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitates, concerned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know...the decision'll clear the way for new planes and route contracts. There's only a small float out there, so you should grab it. Good for a five point pop. Ollie comes back in, as excited as he ever will get under his rolls of flesh, his voice deadpan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... just got 250,000 shares at 18 1/4 from Janson, think I'll pull twice that at 18 1/2 outta the California pensions. We got close to half a million shares in the bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, the Terminator! Blow 'em away Ollie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, I'm pretty sure we got the Beezer Brothers out of Tulsa coming in with us and I'm working on the Silverberg boys in Canada.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rip their throats out and put them in your garbage compactor. (to Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting. You got a card? Buddy thrusts a card into his hands. Gekko glances at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My home number's on the back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles, looks at card)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud Fox, I look at a hundred ideas a day. I choose one. Bud stuffs his notes back into the briefcase, hoping for word of encouragement in the awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hope to hear from you, sir. He turns and heads out the door, still shaken by the revelation he has made passing Susan who hurries in with dossier. Gekko glances at it. As Bud leaves, he overhears:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK gang, looks like we're going over 5% in Teldar, start the lawyers on a tender offer and 13D, we keep going after everything in sight but don't pay over $22. They're gonna fight, they got Myers and Thromberg doing their legal, they make Nazis look like nice guys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud walks glumly past Natalie, certain that he's blown it She's busy on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...thanks Natalie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (buzzing inside, preoccupied)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...have a nice day Mr. Stone. (wrong name, doesn't notice, to Gekko on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Mr. Gekko, the conference call is ready. Mr. Sugarman and Mr. Lorenzo in Delaware. Mr. Bernard in Los Angeles. Mr. Jackson and Ms. Rosco in London. They're all on. The phone call goes behind closed doors. Bud walks out, dejected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud comes in, distracted, punches into his quatron. Telda Paper comes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (comes over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...well, see him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mind on the computer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but he didn't see me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheer up buddy buddy. You shook Gekko the Great's hand and you still got all your fingers. He's not the only elephant in the jungle. INSERT: TELDAR PAPER. The quotron. Bud's eyes. Thinking t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... got something from him? Teldar Paper? Bud wipes it off the screen, his mind made up, dismissing the temptation to buy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a dog with fleas. Lynch, the manager, stalks past with some telexes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you been the last 3 hours, Fox? I wouldn't be sitting around chin wagging if I were you... plenty of names in that phone book to cold call... Marvin gives Lynch the Italian salute, behind his back. Grudgingly, Buddy flips open the massive New York phone b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...got tickets for the Knicks tonight. Go out and cruise some bimbos afterwards, whaddaya say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...gotta read my reports.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget charts! We're not fund managers, Bud, churn 'em and burn 'em. I'm offering you the Knicks and chicks. God save you before you turn into poor Steeples over there. Their eyes briefly on DAN STEEPLES, red faced, desperatel trying to make a sale on the telephone, hangs up defeated

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...preferably Lou Mannheim... Their eyes briefly on LOU MANNHEIM, in his private office sitting there slumped, thinking, smoking as he watches th quotron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice guy but a loser. Lost all his equity when his firm went belly up in the recession of 71. you wanna be coming in here in your late sixties still pitching? ... Whatever happened to that cute analyst at Thudder, Wicks? ... Cindy? Susan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cindy. Having sex with her is like reading the Wall Street Journal 'cept the Journal don't talk back. 'Sides this AIDS crap is ruining romance, nobody trusts anybody anymore, gotta get a blood test in the toilet before you leave a bar together, somebody oughtta invent an AIDS dipstick, no kidding, make a fortune. I gotta get to work... Z's today. (hitting the phone with the directory)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pool SECRETARY, GINA, calls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call for you Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud Fox. Bud rears up in his seat. A change. Marvin notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gekko talks into his speaker phone, gazing out the window

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright Bud Fox... buy me twenty thousand shares of Bluestar. No more than 15 1/8, 3/8 tops, and don't screw it up sport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera tracks around and in on him climactically as t Music Theme rises to ensnare him... We end close on Bud. Dumbstruck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Thank you. You won't regret it. He hangs up, stunned still, rises from his chair, unbutto his collar and feverishly starts writing the ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a little action there, eh buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marv, (turns triumphant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I just bagged the elephant!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The upper West Side. The young, the rich and the restless parade along the avenue, jamming the neighborhood restaur and bars. Bud glides along, feeling a part of the crowd n past a dreadlocked DERELICT swigging Thunderbird and shouting obscenities, shaking a wooden African spear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside a glitzy neighborhood singles bar in which Bud sto everybody seems to be young and drinking margueritas. Bud orders a beer, surveying the room like a veteran, overhea the conversation of a YOUNG TRADER to two other broker ty

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...you know Marty Wyndham? He netted $650,000 out of that merger...26 years old, the guy's Rambo. Got himself a Porsche Turbo Cabriolet about 75 thou, got a house in Westhampton, penthouse on Second Avenue, gets up at 2:30 in the morning, he's in the office at 4...guy never sleeps...Rambo genes... He blathers on as Bud surveys the room, noticing an ELEGA BLONDE with a striking aloof beauty, very much the debuta dream Grace Kelly type, so refined that you wonder what s could possibly be doing out at night in public alone. Bud summons his courage, catches his breath, makes his wa over... She sees him approach, obviously doesn't wish to talk, eyes darting elsewhere like a nervous deer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awkward)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi...can I buy you a drink? I'm celebrating tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disdainful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, no thanks... (looking away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I know you get approached a lot by dubious men, but I'm different, I never talk to strangers, all my life I've been waiting for the right person to walk across the room... you're that person, you don't know it but I do and if you walk away now I'll never see you again or you me. You'll grow old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll grow old. We'll both die. And we'll never have known each other. That's sad. At least one drink for a dreamer...What's your favorite drink? She looks at him, not quite sure. Is he serious or glib?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncommitted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grand Marnier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like a french word, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a romantic and tragic drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds tempting. I prefer mine with a twist of fate. You know like us meeting. Don't go away... Maybe, just maybe she's his! His eyes show it as he hurri back to the bar to order. As he gets the bartender's attention, he turns and sees that she is joined by a MAN looks as if he stepped out of the pages of GQ. Together t walk away. Stung, Bud watches as the woman of his dreams disappears out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I just lost it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud and a DATE he's obviously just picked up, are struggl to be seen in a mass of people trying to get in the hotte new club in Manhattan. Bud easing forward along the ropes a large BOUNCER who roughly pushes one of the bridge-and- tunnel kids back across the rope. Joe discreetly shows him $50 but they guy says: "No room! humiliating him in front of his date. The bouncer shoving Bud aside as Gordon Gekko and KATE, his wife, and ENTOURA (ALEX, others) are shown through the ropes into the door. Bud says something to Gordon but it gets lost in the conf EXT. 79TH STREET & BROADWAY - EARLY DAY People pouring into the subway on the way to work. Bud rifles through the Financial Times he's just bought at th newsstand and finds the article he was looking for: BLUES EXONERATED IN 1984 CRASH. He thrusts his fist in the air, victoriously...bounds down the subway stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud's on the quotron and the phone; the word's spread aro the office, he's landed Gekko and brokers drop by his des to get the lowdown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it at now? Still moving. Great!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man of the day. Pour some water on him to cool him off...one of these days I want to know how you got Gekko's account.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating Dan's Yale tie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My magic tie, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll trade you. Lou Mannheim and a Chinese LADY BROKER intersect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordo the Great, way to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good little company. I remember when we got the money for Bluestar to build those first planes, back in the fifties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you're buying Teldar. Bud smiles back at her mischievously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleep with me and the secrets of the West are yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's a crap company, sure you'll make money on the takeover rumor, but what's being created. Nothing. No substance behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (succinct)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old values. Buy. She hears him. As they go, Marvin swivels madly over in h chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy, buddy, some buddy; why didn't you tell me to buy Bluestar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Marv, he demanded confidentiality...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme a break. You buy Bluestar Airlines yesterday. Today they just happen to get good news and the stock goes bat shit. You must have ESP. A real Nostradamus. (Bud ignoring him, picking up the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, what are friends for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I owe you one Marv.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, next time a little birdie talks to you, talk to me too E.F. Hutton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pool secretary)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy, phone...Gordon Gekko! Everybody in the adjacent area turns and looks at Buddy l in an E.F. Hutton commercial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Natalie...lunch at 21? (looks at watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm out the door... As he springs up to leave, Lynch the manager happens to b strolling by. He nods pleasantly at Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice piece of work, Fox. Why don't you join me and the partners for lunch tomorrow in the dining room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to, Mr. Lynch, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark mahagony wood, plush banquettes, a long oak bar. Bud enters the main dining room in a relatively outre suit th hangs on him embarrassingly as other businessmen in well- suits move around him and a Maitre d' sniffs, then leads to where Gekko is parked, finishing up his lunch. A half finished plate is removed to make way for Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi sport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still nervous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to see you again Mr. Gekko. He's seated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try the steak tartare. It's off the menu but Louis'll make it for you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course sir. And to drink? He looks at Gekko's bottled water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh...just a Evian, thank you... The Maitre d' leaves. Gekko proudly pulls a tiny 3" by 6" color television out of his pocket with a 2" diagonal screen, flips it on to the Dow Jones avarages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See this? Can you believe it? Two inch screen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I can't even see it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...for my kid Rudy -- 3 years old, electronics freak, got a liquid crystal display 'stead of an electronic beam. We're going into a new age pal. So how's business today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bluestar was at 21 and an eighth when I left the office. It might spin up to 25 by the bell...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a tiny smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teldar's shooting up. Buy any for yourself? Bet you were on the phone two minutes after you got out of my office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flushes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir, that would've been illegal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't believe him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure...relax sport, no one's gonna blow a whistle. Here, is this legal?...you wanna put it in my account? As he fishes a check out and drops it on Bud's plate. Greeting TWO BANKERS who stop at the table as Bud picks u the check, glances at it. His hand starts to tremble. The check is for $500,000.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to bus boy, the bankers excited)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we have the check over here for christ's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rushing off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cover the Bluestar buy and put a couple hundred thou in one of those bow-wow stocks you mentioned. Pick the dog with the least fleas. Use a stop loss so your downside is 50,000, and buy yourself a decent suit. You can't come in here looking like that. (Bud flushes, embarassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to Morty Sills, Tell 'em I sent you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his genuine look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gekko -- thank you for the chance. You won't regret this, you're with a winner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (paying the check with cash)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...put the rest of it in a money market account for now. I want to see what you know before I invest it...and save the cheap salesman talk, it's obvious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stung)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me sir. Gekko rising to leave, the Maitre d' hovering around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard me...I don't like losses sport. Nothing ruins my day more than losses... You do good, you get perks, all kinds of perks. Stay home tonight. Louis, take care of 'im. Enjoy the lunch. Confused, Bud watches Gekko walk out of the room, pumping extended hands left and right. He holds the cashiers chec up to his eyes, entranced by it, like a kid with his firs dollar...as the raw steak tartare with an egg on top is p in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud is at his computer when the door bell rings. He's not expecting a visitor. When he opens the door he is knocked for a loop. A smashing looking LADY in a fitted Chanel suit, ropes of chains, short tight skirt, beautiful long legs, is standi there. Taking in the apartment, she hides her distaste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Bud, I'm Lisa, a friend of Gordon's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a daze)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa. Gordon? Oh, Mr. Gekko. Sure. Would you, uh, like to come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't he tell you? (sighs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's so like Gordon. Get dressed, we're going out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stretch limo is parked in front, neighborhood WINOS inspecting it. The CHAUFFEUR opens the back door, as Lisa steps inside, Buddy in tow. The winos clap, howling at he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud in the back seat next to Lisa, gazes out the black tinted window as they drive away, then turns to her as sh gives him a bottle of Champagne to open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wherever you like, Lutece, 21, the River Cafe...or maybe we can just drive around for a while. (provocatively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work up an appetite. She crosses her legs. Bud's eyes moving south. He pops th cork. Lisa does a little blow, offers him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want some? (he shorts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon tells me you're a very talented broker. What do you like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeling the rush)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like? Uh...hmmm. Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got this guy who should know tells me buy Hewlitt Packard but I been burned on tips. What do you think Bud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see, it closed at uh, 41 1/8... (his voice cracking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up a quarter...very attractive... about average yield... She unzips his fly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rising profits...strong balance sheets, good earnings per share.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (removing her blouse)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're hot on this stock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods, moaning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's ready to take off. I'd jump all over it if I were you. As she pulls up her skirt and climbs on top of Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy, in an obviously new Mort Sills suit, struts past Carolyn at the reception desk, in high spirits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning Buddy, you look happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any better and I'd be guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up the flow)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were never that innocent sugarpie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coyly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...how do you know? You wish...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud on the phone, gazing at the ticker, concern in his ey CLICKING of the tape ticker comes up over the music. He looks at Marv.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Research reports piling up. Bud's secretary trying get his attention. Bud's concern growing, as the green fluorescent numbers spit across the board. CLICKER growin louder. Pan to Marvin, hands cupped in prayer. To Dan Steeples who closes his eyes and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close. Bud watching the tape -- dizzying, hypnotic blur o numbers. The roar of the clicker, drowning out the music. runaway freight train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud's hands clamped over his eyes. The numbers stop. Nois recedes. He opens his eyes, looks down at his desk, stack with reports and phone messages, as the pool secretary, GINA, calls out. Marvin glumly coasts over in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, we sure went down the toilet on that ugly bitch. If we were Japs, we'd have to stay with our aircraft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gekko's office is after you. Be at the Wyatt Club courts at six... Bud looks worried, at Marvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Games in progress on the four courts, heavy hitting sound Crossing to Gekko and Bud going at it. Bud is obviously t worse for wear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...come on sport, you gotta try harder, I need some exercise for chrissake...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out of breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gekko, I don't think I can...go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...finish out the game, Bud, push yourself... Meant paternally or sadistically, it's hard to tell. Gekk hits the ball, a big fat shot. Bud returns, Gekka moves h around the court, as if punishing him, the kid exhausted the ball's never quite out of reach -- till Bud finally can't take it anymore and at the end of his breath, smash into the wall and collapses. Gekko laughs. Bud lying ther like a sad dog as Gekka hauls him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The public is out there throwing darts at a board, sport. I don't throw darts at a board. I only bet sure things. Read Sun Tzu's "The Art of War." 'every battle is won before it is ever fought.' Think about it. He exits the squash court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gekko and Bud sit alone, wreathed in steam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice club, Mr. Gekko...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... not bad for a City College boy. Bought my way into this club and now every one of these ivy league schmucks is sucking my kneecaps...I just got on the Board of the Zoological Society, cost me a million; that's the thing with WASPS -- they like animals but they can't stand people!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easing into it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, Mr. Gekko, we took a little loss today. We got stopped out on Tarafly... (Gekko waits)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...about 50 thousand. Gekko's expression is frightening but cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess your father's not a union representative on that company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs, shocked)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? How do you know about my father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The most valuable commodity I know of is information. Wouldn't you agree on that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exhaling deeply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy is slumped on a bench after taking a shower, drinki a Coke. Gekko towelling himself down, getting dressed...n man constantly stopping by to greet him. Hi Fred, hi Barr how's the wife...still living in Larchmont? Yeah, still commuting... y'ever do anything with that Aetna Gas deal...nah...fishing for information, for a possible drin or meeting but Gekko stonewalls them all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not as smart as I thought you were, Buddy boy, Listen hard -- don't count on Graham and Dodd to make you a fortune, everybody in the market knows the theory, ever wonder why fund managers can't beat the S&P 500? 'Cause they're sheep -- and the sheep get slaughtered. I been in the business since '69. Most of these high paid MBAs from Harvard never make it. You need a system, discipline, good people, no deal junkies, no toreadores, the deal flow burns most people out by 35. Give me PSHs -- poor, smart and hungry. And no feelings. You don't win 'em all, you don't love 'em all, you keep on fighting, and if you need a friend, get a dog, it's trench warfare out there sport... (eyeing the surroundings)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and in here too. I got twenty other brokers out there, analyzing Charts. I don't need another one. Talk to you sometime... He turns to go, Bud panicking. Is this the kissoff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with all his conviction)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not just another broker Mr. Gekko. If you give me another chance, I'll prove it to you. I'll go the extra yard for you. One more chance. Please... Gekko looks back, a beat, walks over to Bud, thrusts his towel hard at his stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want one more chance? Then stop sending me information and start getting me some. Get dressed, I'll show you my charts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cruising up Park Avenue. A panel slides open next to the with a portable computer on it. A television is turned on the evening news, a low hum of voices. Gekko punches into the keyboard of the computer. A name appears an the scree LAWRENCE WILDMAN with curriculum vitae following; address phones, businesses...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know the name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Course. Larry Wildman. One of the first raiders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused, cold hatred)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Larry Wildman. Like all Brits he thinks he was born with a better pot to piss in... bribed an old secretary of mine to open bar mouth and stole RDL Pharmaceuticals right out from under me. Wildman the white knight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember that deal. You were involved? Gekko shuts off the computer and slides it back into the housing, his eyes taking in the low-volume news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revenge is a dish best served cold... well, it's payback time, sport. (looking out suddenly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... see that building? I bought into it ten years ago. It was my first real estate deal. I sold it a couple of years later and made an $800,000 dollar profit. It was better than sex. At that time I thought that was all tne money in the world... (drinks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, it's a day's pay ... I had a mole in Wildman's employ. Gave me half the picture, then he got fired...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wildman's in town. He just became an American citizen. Something big's about to go down. I want to know where he goes and who he sees. I want you, sport, to give me the missing half of the picture...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow him? Mr. Gekko I... (shaken)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not what I do. I could lose my license. If the SEC found out, I could go to jail. It's inside information, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scratches his head wryly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside information. Oh you mean like when a father tells his son about a court ruling on an airline? Or someone overhears me saying I'm gonna buy Teldar Paper? Or the chairman of the board of XYZ suddenly knows it's time to blow out XYZ. You mean that? (a piercing look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid sport, unless you got a father on the board of directors of another company, you and I are gonna have a hard time doing any business... Bud downs the rest of his drink, upset by the darkening m There's something very powerful and frighteninq about Gek

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about hard work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about it? You work hard. I'll bet you stayed up all night analyzing that dog you bought. And where'd it get you?... my father worked hard too like an elephant pushing electrical supplies. And he dropped dead at 49 with a heart attack and a tax bill and the bank pissed on his grave and took the house; my mom ended up working in a dish factory... Wake up pal, if you're not inside you're outside. And I'm not talking a $200,000 a year working Wall Street stiff flying first class and being "comfortable", I'm talking rich pal, rich enough to fly in your own jet, rich enough not to waste time, 50-100 million, a player Bud -- or nothing. You had what it takes to let through my door. Next question: You got what it takes to stay...?? The car stopping in traffic. Horns honking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look out there... THEIR POV -- a STREET CORNER. A richly dressed EXECUTIVE stands at the curb next to the BUM with a shopping cart filled with garbage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really think the difference 'tween this guy and that guy is luck? Mohammed, pull over. The car pulls over. Gekko checks his watch, pulls out the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...when it comes to money, sport, everybody's of the same religion. Or should be... Hope you don't mind if I let you off here, I'm late for a meeting. Good bye, nice knowing you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CHAUFFEUR lets Bud out the door... Bud looks back at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Mr. Gekko...you got me. His eyes telling us he is weighed down by chains of guilt Gekko smiles, gazes at the twilight skyline, a sudden loo of contentment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's a beautiful night. I love this hot stinkin' city. (pointing up Park Avenue)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... nothing else like it in the world. Seven million people living on each other's heads, kids born, millionaires dying, people praying, junkies, whores, wills, lawyers, deals, parties, sex... guys like you sport -- dreaming about the big score. You know the best thing about New York is everything you can do here. And the worst thing is everything you can't do here... He shuts the door. Bud watches as the limo drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud, in a suit, waits next to a motorcycle across from on of the most desirable addresses in New York. The Doorman rushes to open the door under the canopy as a tall strong man in his fifties emerges with a LAWYER TYPE and a FEMALE EXECUTIVE. The man is SIR LAWRENCE WILDMAN a his manner and gait convey the impression of an authorita presence with little patience as the chauffeur opens the door and he slides into the back seat of the limo. Buddy, astride Marv's Kawasaki 500, hits the streets afte him. The music through the following Montage should sugge a chase brio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud shooting past the Trinity Church structure... Wildman gets out of his limo with his people, strides into the lo Bud quickly parks his bike on the sidewalk and rushes in after them... not a second too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud just manages squeeze in the elevator with Wildman and crew -- and -- a couple of other early birds -- as the do close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud eyeing Wildman, looks away as Wildman looks back at h an edge of defiance to him, why are you staring at me? No the world's most likeable personality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors open and Wildman and Co. step out into the reception area of Kahn, Seidelman... The doors close and Buddy continues upward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street now jammed with people hurrying to work. Buddy paces the curb, reacting when Wildman walks out, saying goodbye to the female executive and getting in the limo w his lawyer... Buddy follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Formal French haute cuisine. Power lunches in progress. A Wildman is seated with several well-dressed BANKERS at a good table, Bud tries to wrangle a table (next to Mr. Wildman on top of everything from a stiff looking Maitre who shakes his head, barely concealing his attitude towar Buddy's youth and general demeanor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy waits outside, bored, as Wildman steps out, shakes hands with the bankers... Bud making an entry into his notebook like any good spy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music rising to triumphant proportions. AERIAL SHOT of Li emerging from the tunnel and onto the Long Island Express CAMERA MOVES IN, picking up Buddy on the Kawasaki, dartin through lanes, staying several car lengths behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Limo winds its way along the perimeter road, past commercial airliners. It takes the turnoff for Butler Aviation. Buddy exits the ramp shortly after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A corporate saberliner jet, its engines running, idles at the end of the taxiway. The limo pulls up along the tarma next to it and Wildman steps out, walking past a MECHANIC the stairs of the plane. A STEWARDESS waits for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud watches, wondering what to do as the plane taxies dow the runway. He spots the flight mechanic and the answer comes to him. He starts running towards the mechanic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud races up to the mechanic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit, don't tell me Mr. Wildman was on board that plane? (the mechanic nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My boss is gonna kill me. I was supposed to give him this. (holding his notebook)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know where that plane is going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erie, Pennsylvania...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone, proudly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...after spending the morning at Kahn, Seidelman -- on the 14th floor, the junk bond department -- where Shane Mora works -- he had lunch at La Cirque with a group of well-dressed heavyset bean- counters... (Gekko voice back: "the adjectives are redundant, sport")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...he later stopped off at Morgan. I'd say from all the palm-pressing and sweet smiling going on that Larry got some nice fat financing... G.G.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex and Susan are with him. Gekko playing the computer, eyes lighting up on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...bright but not bright enough, Sherlock, roll the dice and play a little monopoly... what box would Sir Lawrence land on in Erie, Pennsylvania?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud slapping his face, realizing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, he's buying Anacott Steel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon already has the closing figures punched up on his quotron. Calls his shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the market opens tomorrow, buy five thousand March fifty calls. You hear me? Start buying ten thousand share blocks and take it up to fifty dollars. When it reaches fifty, you can let out a little taste to your friends. Then call this number -- 555-7617: tell the man "blue horseshoe loves Anacott Steel..." You scored, Buddy! Be in touch. (hangs up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up, looks at Alex and Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start buying Anacott Steel all over the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large company banner hangs from the rafters: "Bluestar The Vision Goes On." Buddy's father, Carl, Charley Dent a Dominick Amato are changing the generator on a 727. A wel is repairing a wing seam. Buddy shouting to his Dad over noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Dad!... Hi ya Charlie... Dominick... They wave back, Carl climbing down a maintenance stand... lights up a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What brings you out here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Client. Got a private jet over at Butler Aviation... Dad, you always gotta light up when you see me, it's the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (don't bother me look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't start, alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Why so pissed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn fare wars are murdering us. Had to lay off five guys. Nothing I could do. What is it... money? Bud takes out his wallet, smiles, peels out 10 $100 bills

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it is. In fact I'm doing great. New client. Whole new league. It's starting to happen Dad. The Big Leagues! You know what I'm saying. He sticks the cash in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure...lots of guys at the track talk like that... but how do you know you'll have any dough next month... (looking at the money)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this? I gave you two hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dividend. I figure I owe you about five thousand in nickels and dimes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tries to give it back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...don't be crazy. Put it to your school loans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about the loans. I'm doing good Dad and it's gonna stay that way now... least buy yourself a new suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I need a fancy suit for. I don't hobnob with the jet set. I just fix their planes. Buddy forces the money into his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...then buy yourself a decent bowling jacket so when you take Mom out you don't look like the Roto Rooter man. Come on, for godsakes, that's what money's for. Enjoy yourself... Touched, his father shakes his head and smiles. He takes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Problem with money is you never have enough or you got too much -- and when you got it you're never happy 'cause somebody's always trying to take it away from you. Money's one giant pain in the ass y'ask me... thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (admiration)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Dad, you should've been a CEO. How about dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever night you like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (remembering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait... next week's booked. Let me check with my girl and get back to you on Monday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs at his new lifestyle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you do that huckleberry. I'll still be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...gotta run Dad. You stop smoking, you hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud silent, an intent look on his face, gazing up at the digital clock... as it flicks to 9:30... post time. Tickers, squawk boxes and shouting erupt. Bud calls in his order: "10,000 AN STL 46... and let me k how the options are opening." Music skips along in a revolving madcap fashion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CLERK hands the buy order to the FLOOR MANAGER. He star writing a ticket as we pull back:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Company floor traders are jammed into a narrow booth, frantically takinq orders over phones and telex machines. The FLOOR MANAGER gives the ticket to a RUNNER, a young m wearing worn sneakers, who dashes off.
