We follow him acro the scruffy Exchange Floor, as he weaves through a crush traders crammed around horseshoe-shaped kiosks, cathode-r tubes slung above them, displaying the latest prices in bright, green letters and numbers. Intermittent shrieks a howls, calls to buy and sell, issue from the far reaches the labyrinthian room. As in the final leg of a relay race, the RUNNER hands the ticket off to a COMPANY TRADER, who is buying and selling the post where Anacott Steel is traded. The TRADER checks the ticket and turns to the SPECIALIST, executing the ord The camera moves up as the Anacott Steel (AN STL) quote flashes across the broad tape -- as the price ticks up fr 46 to 46 1/4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud paces nervously at his desk, looking at his quotron. STL appears on the screen, now up to 47. Bud puts in anot order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SAME RUNNER races over, handing Bud's next TICKET to COMPANY TRADER. Tilt up to the broad tape. As ANACOTT STEEL, AN STL, rises to 48 1/8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Bud, eating a sandwich, eyes glued to the ticker. AN S has climbed to 48 3/4. Marv stalks by, shouting on the ph Bud looks away from the ticker, pretending to read a repo When Marv disappears, Bud hastily calls in at 49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the tired RUNNER dodging through the crowd, and over t the TRADER handing him a new ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on the OFFICE TICKER -- as Anacott Steel hits 50. Buddy jumps up from his chair, and animatedly crosses to Marv who is on the phone, cold calling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Mr. Ehrlich I've got important financial news! It concerns his future. Bud presses down on the phone button, cutting him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anacott Steel. Buy it. Marv looks at Joe and sees a look on his face that he's never seen before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anacott Steel -- right. Bud leaves, Marv re-dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Beltzer, you're gonna love this! Lou Mannheim hangs up the phone, a troubled look. Bud lea into his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Mannheim, got a sure thing. (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anacott Steel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scoffs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No such thing Bud - 'cept death and taxes. Not a good company anymore, no fundamentals. What's going on Bud? Do you know something? (Bud uncomfortable, Lou reads it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember there're no short cuts son, quick buck artists come and go with every bull market but the steady players make it through the bear markets. (Bud anxious to go)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're part of something here, Bud. The money you make for people creates science and research jobs. Don't sell that out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, Mr. Mannheim, but you gotta get to the big time first, then you can be a pillar and do good things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't get a little bit pregnant, Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a winner Mr. Mannheim, trust me -- buy. (exits)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie Cushing's on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotcha baby, its do-able... meet you at the Wyatt Club... 3pm Dinner Thursday... Indochina. Then we'll kamikaze down to Nell's, chase a little cotton underwear--I know this 18 year old bimbo, man... you can take it to the bank... (hangs up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intersects)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanna play some tennis Saturday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean teach you how to play. Can't. Going fly fishing in Canada, big client...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disappointed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...you take that Anacott Steel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (winks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...light snack, but good, thanks pal, you're sharking your way up... Dan Steeples's talking confidentially on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just heard the most lovely two words... 'Anacott Steel.' Buddy dialing the phone number that Gekko gave him. He speaks into the receiver, in a hushed voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Blue horseshoe loves Anacott Steel. (hangs up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The REPORTER on the other end of the phone hangs up. He rises from his desk, strides across the busy news floor, over to an ASSOCIATE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anacott Steel's in play. Check the arbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wind and waves. Gekko's modern, Sante Fe structure house sits on a dune overlooking the grey Atlantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweeten the offer, throw 2 bucks more in a convertible preferred. And 5 year contracts for themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Immense slanted ceilings, a vast clean modern space fille with dozens of contemporary art objects, junk sculptures, floor to ceiling windows radiating light, that look out o cantilevered deck and pool - and the ocean beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Cromwell wants to play financial chicken with me, we'll see who swerves first. Where the hell's Gene? Gekko slumps down on a sofa, exhausted, watching one of several news reports he master-controls with a remote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sent him to Vermont to get the deposition from the CEO Cromwell fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...done and done. Night gang, and Susan no legs waving in the air tonight. I want you dreaming about Teldar Paper. During this, RUDY, Gordon's 3 year-old son, drives in in latest electronic baby toy -- a Porsche-bodied electric c Gekko hangs up, checks out a Reuters quotron positioned n

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy Kazootee, how's my cutie! The kid jumps out of the car and scoots into his father's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy bad boy! Bad boy! -- play with Wudi... Now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not now Rudy. Daddy's making money to buy you toys. Daddy work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy work bad boy! Gordon absently tossles Rudy's hair, his eyes glued to th TV. The kid senses it, jumps back off his lap and into th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the big story tonight is Anacott Steel which closed at 51 1/8.  Up 5 1/8 from yesterday's close on heavy trading... Kate, Gordon's beautiful, raven-haired wife, homemaker an antiquer, enters with the bovine-eyed AU PAIR GIRL from France... just at Rudy drives his car into a wall where i stalls, engines grinding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think somebody's playing hooky from the bathtub. Rudy, say good night DAddy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (can't hear, to Kate)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut that off, willya! Kate, upset with the noise, tries to pull her son nicely of the car. The Korean HOUSEBOY coming in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calls for you, sir, a reporter from Time magazine on two, says it's important... and a Mr. Fox on three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEKKO (annoyed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I come to the country and it's worse than the city! I'm not home... (changes mind, pushes in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gekko, I've been trying to reach you. We got the options. We got a good execution on them! Meanwhile, the kid has no intention of going anywhere and plants his feet and emits the loudest shrieking this side the fat lady in the opera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicole! Take him will you... Handing the bawling, writhing mass of anger to Nicole as it were laundry she doesn't want to touch... Nicole takes him screaming out of the room... Gordon trying to concent on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papers and charts are strewn around, trailing down to a b of take-out pizza and empty beer bottles. Bud has stayed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost apologetic, speeding on the high of the buy...)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got all I could get which was 750,000 shares plus 5000 March 50 calls. Average price of $47 a share And $4 per contract for the call. I just wish I could've got more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't expect to get it all, sport, you'll burn out. First rule of business is never get emotional about stock, clouds the judgment. Where do we stand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BUSINESS ANALYST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In response to an inquiry from the New York Stock Exchange, management issued a terse no comment. Wildman would not return phone calls. Analysts believe the company is worth $75 per share in a transaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Carmen are here and the Livingstons are on their way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods, listening to phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right there, fix them a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shifting the figures)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...we have 37.2 million invested. At this point, we're up 3.1 million and some change. If it goes to 75 bucks we can clean close to 12 mill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're walking between the raindrops kid. I expect Sir Larry is choking on his royal chamber pot by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My firm needs your signature on these option agreements tonight, sir, otherwise we could take a real bath tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Can't it wait? I'm good for it. (Bud waits, "Sir")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Awright. Come out, get the directions from Natalie and hurry up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud's P.O.V. as he pulls up to an austere, ultra- sophisticated monolith of glass and wood dominating a stretch of dune overlooking the Atlantic's angry surf. Several Jags, state of the art Jeeps and a Rolls are draw up outside. Bud, getting out of his faded Honda, goes up the stairs t the door. He rings several times. A BLACK BUTLER opens it and looks at Buddy somewhat waril Laughter and voices are heard from inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pretentiously: high English accent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud Fox. Got some papers for Mr. Gekko to sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a moment please. Without thinking he closes the door in Joe's face. He sta there, harrassed peering around through a window on the l A small gathering of friends in progress around a glowing fireplace. The butler waves him in from the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud enters, as Gekko approaches.  He seems annoyed to be disturbed at his country home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apologetic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mr. Gekko.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes the papers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allright. Wait here... About to go when his wife, Kate Gekko, comes over. A pret dark-haired woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Problems?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... Bud Fox, my wife, Kate... They exchange pleasantries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You came from the city? (with a look to Gordon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long drive, have a drink. Gekko doesn't seem to like the idea, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, why not, Bud boy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kate's walking back inside to her guests, as Bud sidles o to Gekko.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...if you'd rather not, Mr. Gekko, I can leave...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They cross to the main living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It's okay Buddy, you know Alex... Candice Rogers. (Alex and his date shake hands, faintly aloof)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...This is Stone Livingston... and his wife Muffie. (a young stuffy banker in weekend corduroys looks at Bud as if he obviously doesn't belong)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Darien Taylor, Sam Ruspoli, Carmen Winters, Dick Brady... All old friends. Bud looking wide-eyed at the beautiful "Calvados" BLONDE he's been dreaming of for weeks... she's with Mr. GQ and doesn't recognize Bud, nods back, they all nod back, naturally suspicious of the young outsider... Rudy's TOY ROBOT wheels  around the floor with a drink on its tray, talking computer talk...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (charmed by it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...good idea Gordon, good help is hard to find these days but can he whip up a dry vodka martini...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...well he doesn't talk back or steal the silver and Dick's gonna get me an exemption on him, aren't you... (Dick Brady is obviously an accountant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud plucks a glass of wine from the robot's tray and plun himself down on a sofa, overhearing the conversation betw Muffie Livingston and Candice Rogers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...there I am in St. Kitt's in my new Kamali leopard skin V-cut bikini which is going to turn back the clock on our marriage five years, you know what I mean, and I can't even fit into it, my skin's all pink and inflamed, and I look like a walking social disease all because this Ukranian bitch botched the wax on my bikini line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (revolted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god, how ghastly, you should sue her... The Korean houseboy has come over to Gekko.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call for you sir. Sir Larry Wildman, he says it's important... Bud tightens, so does the whole room hearing the name of moment. Gekko smiles at Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to houseboy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make Mr. Livingston a martini would you Nyung, and this gentleman... (to Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stick around, this could be fun... He goes to the alcove to take the call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, I had to sit around the beach wearing a moo-moo for 10 days, my whole vacation ruined. (noticing as Bud laughs, chokes on the wine, spilling some on the couch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just spilled your wine. Bud noticing the stain, starts wiping it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just making it worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry, what a surprise... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can it wait till tomorrow. I got some people over. (dryly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...if you feel that way Larry, come over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blonde, DARIEN TAYLOR, is examining a modern sculptur as Buddy comes over with two Calvados.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello again, I been holding these drinks for us for the last three weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomprehending)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grand Marnier. A romantic and tragic drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, I remember you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Destiny took us apart, but I knew it would bring us back together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aha. Poet or philosopher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stock broker. As in: never have so few done so little for so much. So what do you see in this? Bud indicates the painting in front of them -- a buffalo skull in the desert by Georgia O'Keefe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd give anything to have this in my house, even for a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...few thousand dollars down the drain if you ask me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh really? (looks at him quizically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess you can kiss that career as an art appraiser goodbye, because we paid over four hundred thousand for it at the contemporary picture sale last June.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chokes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could have a great beach house for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you could, in Wildwood, New Jersey. If you sold this, (indicates a Rothko hanging near the O'Keefe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: you could have a pretty nice penthouse on Fifth. But you wouldn't have much left over for decoration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, I thought Gordon was a tough businessman, but somebody's really taking him to the cleaners here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. I'd say that Gordon is one of the most astute collectors around. He has a great eye and he only buys the best. Like this rug for instance, a silk Tabriz, the finest of its kind. The day after he bought it in London, a dealer representing the Saudi Royal Family offered him twice what he paid. It absolutely makes the room. See how this little bit of celadon in the border is picked up in the cushions oh the sofa... although... (she's really warming up to her subject now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if I would have used that tea dipped linen for the upholstery - too dingy. And it's a sacrilege having that Pre-Columbian pot in the center of the coffee table. Some dope might use it as an ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gather you're a decorator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it, a great spender of other people's money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you're that good, you could probably do wonders at my place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upper West Side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (losing interest fast)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh really. Home of the exposed brick wall and the (shudders)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: houseplant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh it's just a rental. I'm moving to the East Side soon. I've got a couple of deals brewing with Gordon. (shifts uncomfortably with his pretension)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: but that's just conversation... what about real things? Like dinner. The two of us. Friday. Cafe. Santo Domingo. Bud waits, staring suddenly and deeply into her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I have a previous engagement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Break it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess this must be destiny alright. My first yuppie apartment and... (pats him on the cheek flirtatiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: my first yuppie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gives her a steely glare)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may call me a yuppie... It's Mister Yuppie to you. They both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gets serious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. See you Friday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really do believe in destiny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only if I want something bad enough. Her date, Mr. GQ, SAMMY RUSPOLI intersects with Kate. A cultivated European air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...there you go again, Darien, talking with strange men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's our Darien: elusive, reclusive, exclusive. (to Sam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Bud right? He works for Gordon... (Sam nodding, makes conversation, big smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam's in banking. You staying for dinner Bud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitant, eyes Darien)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm afraid I've got to get some work... Kate noticing the doorbell ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...excuse me. Sam muttering something in Darien's ear of an intimate nature. She glides away with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me next week, I'll give you an estimate... An ironic promise in her eyes... Bud ecstatic inside... looks over, goes to the foyer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIR LARRY WILDMAN walks in, his country gentleman clothin somewhat softening his imposing figure but not the cultur rapacious eagle's face. With him a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (strained)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry, how have you been? Get you a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slightly impatient)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh fine. Travelling actually. Nothing thank you. Is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon?... He's right here. As Gordon intersects, casually tasting a spot of the dinn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry! Excuse me "sir" Larry, great to see you again, you're looking good. (handshakes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon... (sniffing the guests and furnishings in the room as if they were stale air)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaving, to Gordon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I'll head back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEKKO (spontaneously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stick around... Larry, one of my "gang" -- Bud Fox. Pleasantries. Bud nervously shakes hands, sensing Wildman might recognize him from being tailed in the elevator. Th indeed is a moment but Wildman's attention blurs as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we go upstairs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon enters a den lined with old books hunting prints; proudly picks up something from his gun collection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rarest pistol in the world, Larry, a .45 Luger. Only six were ever manufactured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations but rarer still is your interest in Anacott Steel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same interest as yours Larry. Money. I thought it'd be a good investment for my kid...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. This time I'm in for the long term. This is not a liquidation, Gordon. I'm going to turn it around. You're getting a free ride on my tail, mate, and with the dollars you're costing me to buy back the stock, I could modernize the plant. I'm not the only one who pays here Gordon. We're talking about lives and jobs; three and four generations of steel workers... A strong hint of the cockney working class east and Londo boy whiffing through his speech and manner. The "mate" is tough and to the point but not insulting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (has to smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be wearing a mask you're laughing so hard behind it Larry. Let's cut the "sir" crap. Correct me if I'm wrong, but when you took CNX Electronics, you laid off 8,000 workers, Jessmon Fruit about 6,000, that airline...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cold, deliberate)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could break you, mate, in two pieces over my knees, you know it, I know it, I could buy you six times ever, I could dump the stock just to burn your ass but I happen to want the company and I want your block of shares. I'm announcing a tender offer at 65 tomorrow, and I'm expecting your commitment. Bud watching this drama unfold. Gekko is about to blow, controls it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showdowns bore me Larry, neither side wins. You can have the company, in fact it's gonna be fun watching you and your giant ego try to make a horserace out of it... (turns to Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think is a fair price for our stock Bud? Bud in the spotlight. The eyes all shift to him -- his moment. After an initial panic, he's cool as a cucumber - and ruthless as his mentor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The break up value is higher. It's worth 80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we don't want to be greedy now, so let's let him have it at $72. His eyes to Wildman who looks at him, cold, icy mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a two bit pirate and a green-mailer, Gekko, nothing more... not only would you sell your mother to make a deal, you'd send her COD... Bud looking sharply as Gekko's eyes flare with hot white

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mail's the same color as yours Larry. Or it was till the Queen started calling you "sir". Now excuse me before I lose my temper... He rises and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gekko stops at the door, a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Considering you brought my mother into it, $71.50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Done. You'll hear from my lawyers. 8 a.m. Good night. He walks out with the silent lawyer. Past Gekko who watch "Ta Ta".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right. I had to sell. The key to the game is your capital reserves. You don't have enough, you can't pee in the tall weeds with the big dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mimicking Gordon now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "All warfare is based on deception..." Sun Tzu says, If your enemy is superior, evade him, if angry, irritate him, if equally matched, fight... if not, split and reevaluate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're learning, sport...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exhausted from the drive back, Bud takes off his sweater tie and collapses onto the bed, closing his eyes. The pho rings. With a start he wakes and answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky is still dark, the first rays of light coming up over the ocean. Gekko, a lonely figure in a windbreaker, restlessly prowls the edge of the beach, waves crashing around him. He's been up all night and has an exhausted, driven look as he whispers over the wind into the cellula phone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money never sleeps pal. When I came in in '69, they traded six hours a day, now the clock don't stop, London's deregulated, the Orient is hungrier than us. Just let the money circle the world, sport, buying and selling, and if you're smart it comes back paying. I just made $800,000 in Hong Kong gold. It's been wired to you -- play with it. You done good, but you gotta keep doing good. I showed you how the game works, now school's out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protests)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gekko, I'm there for you 110%.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand. I want to be surprised...astonish me, sport, new info, don't care where or how you get it, just get it... My wife tells me you put a move on Darien. Here's some inside info for you. That Euroflash GQ guy she's going with's got big bucks but he's putting her feet to sleep. Exit visas are imminent. So don't lose your place in line. (gazing at the surf)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, jeez, I wish you could see this. The lights coming up over the water. I've never seen a painting that captures the beauty of the ocean at this moment. (suddenly fatigued)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...an old Russian proverb - "a fisherman always sees another fisherman from afar." I like you sport, I ever tell you that... Gordon, call me Gordon from now on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Gordon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm gonna make you rich, Bud Fox. I'm gonna make you rich enough you can afford a girl like Darien. Remember, power is the best aphrodisiac. This is your wake-up call. Go to work. He lets the phone drop to his side, staring glazed-eyed a the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SECRETARY leads Bud into the plush, private office of a cocky young lawyer, ROGER BARNES, about tho same age as B his his feet up on the desk, sleepily waving to Buddy to park his ass... The pictures an his walls and desk indica a rich family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox, Bud D. is this deja vu or has it really been a year. You're not hitting me up for NYU are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well we're thinking of putting up a statue of you in the subway. I hear you're moving up in the world. An associate already. Not bad. How's Margie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't complain. Got a house in Oyster Bay. Market treating you good? Still seeing that sexy French gal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, she asked the wrong question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "What are you thinking?"...that was it. The hours are hell, but the money's starting to tumble in. I know this guy who's got an iron- clad way to make money, I can't lose and I can't get hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interested)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, does "this guy" have a tip for an honest lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, check out Teldar Paper, it's still not over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you, I hear you guys are handling the Fairchild Foods merger and it may not be going through. Any surprises I haven't read about in the Wall Street Journal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Buddy, you wouldn't want to got me disbarred now would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (equally casual, looks at the walls)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's listening? It's just one college buddy talking to another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, Roger, everybody's doing it but you don't know, you don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and if I did, what's in it for moi? He obviously has thought about it before. Bud smiles back nonchalant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More money than you ever dreamed, Roger. And the thing is no one gets hurt...how bout a beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (some doubt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too much to do...but I'll walk you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk out past the CLEANING CREWS coming in for the evening, drones of the vacuum cleaners... Bud looks - his POV... A CLEANING WOMAN as she pulls the vacuum cleaner into one of the senior partners offices, t desk crammed with proposals, Bud is lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teasing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Get inside my uncle's door Buddy, all the secrets of the world are yours... the life blood of companies, but you gotta go to law school first...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud comes out of the building and starts walking away. As passes the freight entrance, Bud abruptly notices a van marked MARSALA MAINTENENCE COMPANY. He looks back, thinks for a moment: a look in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud walks past a row of small warehouses and enters one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps into a shabby reception area. A chain-smoking OL LADY looks up from the switch-board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to speak to the owner about some business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The owner, a GREEK with bushy mustache and hardened face, sits at his desk eating lunch, eyeing Bud suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing him a card)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Panos, I've charted the growth of new office space in the city, and I think you're in the right business at the right time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for telling me what I already know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm impressed with your work and I could use a tax break. This is a growing business. Are you interested in some working capital and a partner? Panos puts down his sandwich, measuring Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you think I need a partner?! Bud smiles, ready with his spiel. An elevator opens. A body steps out. A set of keys. Boom past a clipboard and pen to a shirt pocket with MARSALA MAINTENANCE written on it, up to Bud dressed in janitoria clothing. We move with him to the CREW SUPERVISOR who introduces TH CLEANING WOMEN who nervously absorb Bud, worried for thei jobs. Bud strolls from office to office, looking official, overseeing his crew, making notations on a checklist. Bud slips into the Senior Partners' office, thumbs throug calendar on the desk. Sees the list of people, moves to t computer, punches the client's name in. The code number comes up. Bud nods to a SECURITY GUARD down the hall and enters the file room where he looks at the Cleaning Lady and points his watch. As she exits, he scrambles nervously through t files -- finds the code number -- then anxiously flips th pages to the critical tender offer document -- with the target name -- INVESTMENT IN RORKER ELECTRONICS CORP. It' stamped "DRAFT" across the page. His face lights up. The secret to the kingdom. He puts it back, exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gekko on the phone, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud, obviously exhausted from his day and night roles, is telling him something on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud furtively xeroxes a document on a small hand-carried copy machine in his pocket or photographs it if it is too large.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud and Alex, Gekko's assistant, having lunch. Alex gives him the briefcase he's carrying. Pan from Alex to Bud bac to discover Darien in the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud dines with Darien, small talk, intimate looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud is in an office, eyes panning the shelves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you? Bud's head jerks around. A young female PARALEGAL is burn the midnight oil. She looks at him from behind a stack of briefs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (backing off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh. Wrong office. Sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gekko, Kate, Bud, Darien and A FIFTH PERSON roar over the dunes, each in their own dune buggy, laughing and holleri at one another... Buddy driving right up precariously close on Darien, who screams... Buddy flips over his vehicle... comes up laughing... we sense he is getting wilder now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darien rides expertly. A beautiful, immaculately-groomed stallion is being shown to Gekko by the trainer. Bud is sipping wine as he looks on with Kate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got him at an auction in Kentucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fondling the head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close to two million. (Bud whistles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this sucker can go all the way to Devon and the nationals. Darien rides in, smiling to Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Devon? He looks like Seattle Slew. What about the Triple Crown?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not a racehorse, Bud, he's a jumper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would I know? I once bet a horse. He went out at ten to one and came in at quarter to five. He laughs, a little sloppy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darien swims in the ocean, long looping athletic strokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're finishing lunch by the pool framed by a lush flow garden where Kate and son Rudy play. HAROLD SALT, Gekko's chief lawyer, thick glasses, smart eyes and bags of worry that could only come from watching other people's money, looks very city-like in his clothing, examining his paperwork before passing it to Bud, who is the picture of relaxation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You understand Mr. Gekko is constantly barraged with nuisance litigation and IRS audits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...So it's in both our interests to put a safe distance between you and us... (passing a document with a 2nd pen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...this gives you limited power of attorney for Mr. Gekko's account. Every trade you make is at your discretion. Every ticket you buy must be marked "power of attorney." That means you call the shots and Mr. Gekko has no official knowledge of what stocks you're buying. Sign here and here... Buddy looks, then up to Gekko, who smiles, casual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...just the beginning, sport, just the begining... Bud smiles, signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a worrier)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...you understand if any problems arise, you're out there on your own. The trail stops with you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All's fair in love and war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The art of which is deception. Spread the buy orders through different accounts and you won't get burned...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I got some friends that won't mind making some easy money... As Kate drifts over with Rudy and the French au pair GIRL NICOLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy, viens ici, dit bonjour a Monsieur Bud. Rudy either says "No!" or "Bonjour Monsieur Bud!' dependi on the mood of the kid. Gordon sweeping him up and playin with him. The kid squeals with glee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Already speaks a little French, kid got the highest score on his IQ test.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Darien)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...it's so tough to get into a good nursery school now. They even visit your home to make sure your paintings and furnishings are acceptable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it cost these days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: $5,000 just for the tuition... plus the books and supplies... (with a look to Gordon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...some parents even have bodyguards. It's not a bad idea... (picking up Rudy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...now that's it for you with the grown-ups young man. As Rudy smashes the strawberries around his face and resi going. "No! No!" Kate exasperated gives the child to Nico

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicole, take him for a nap, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't nap anymore, Madame. It's been...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stung)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then play with him till he gets tired. We're going out tonight but we like to see him at, let's see, six; give him a bath and put that cute little black suit on him... (to Bud and Gordon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black clothes are the newest things, so chic and milk stains, carrot juice stains just don't show up. Kids -- boy, can they take it out of you! Nicole's "Oui, Madame" is lost in the wrestling match she goes through to drag him out screaming. Kate walking off. Harold gives Buddy another piece of paper...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a contact at one of our banks. On settlement day you'll open an account there for Mr. Gekko under the name of Geneva, Roth Holding Corp. Then you'll wire transfer the money to this account in the Cayman Islands...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising, finished with lunch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think about incorporating yourself there, Bud, Harold will take care of it for you. (with a look to Harold)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... at a reasonable fee. You're gonna make a lot of money now Bud... stakes are gonna go up, no mistakes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...piece of cake, Gordon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera glides off some FISHERMEN hauling their catch their beached boat to Darien who comes tromping out of th surf, water glistening off her lean athletic body. Bud stands before her, cool seductive eyes, holding out a tow She steps up to him and smiles inscrutably. Takes the tow from him, drying herself, instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gazing at the beach)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I could have anything... this would almost do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, almost... Looks at her, stifles his thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teasing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, how did your conference go with Gordon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conference, oh yeah. Fine. We reached an agreement and decided to divide up the world between us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have modest wants. I like that in a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a Turner, a perfect canary diaiaond... a Lear jet... world peace... the best of everything...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, why stop at that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (has to smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not trouble by any chance. Are you? She looks at him, tosses the towel over her shoulder and starts back toward the house. Buddy watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The annual Teldar Paper stockholders' meeting is in sessi 400 stockholders are there -- many middle aged and older, one bag lady. Cromwell sits on an elevated platform at th front of the room surrounded by an army of bulky EXECUTIV none of them weighing less than 200 pounds, ACCOUNTANTS a LAWYERS. Gekko in contrast seems like Robin Hood seated w Alex, Harold, Bud and the other stockholders. Cromwell is delivering his prepared attack on Gekko in a highly sarcastic, gruff manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Your company, ladies and gentlemen, is under siege from Gordon Gekko. Teldar Paper is now leveraged to the hilt, like some piss poor South American country...instead of using our cash to build plants, build our business, all this man really wants is to get paid to withdraw his tender offer and that will cost us approximately another $200 million in greenmail which will be passed on to the consumer... Gekko seething, jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you get off speaking about me like that, making remarks to the press, I resent these remarks, I demand the right to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, sir, you're out of order, haven't you done enough damage to Teldar as it is?...have you no sense of decency? (to shareholders)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can your management... Gekko is urged to sit down by his people but we hear vari catcalls, "Let the man speak!" "Sit down, Gekko!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...concentrate on long term growth when we're busy fighting the get- rich-quick, short term profit, slot machine mentality of Wall Street when we should be fighting Japan! The original fundamental reason for Wall Street was to capitalize American business, underwrite new business, build companies, build America. The "deal" has now succeeded goods and services as America's gross national product and in the process, we are undermining our foundation. This cancer is called "greed". Greed and speculation have replaced long-term investment. Corporations are being taken apart like erector sets, without any consideration of the public good. I strongly recommend you to see through Mr. Gekko's shameless intention here to strip this company and severely penalize the stockholders. I strongly recommend you to reject his tender by voting for management's restructuring of the stock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gekko is now at floor level with a microphone. He's calme makes his pitch to the stockholders, looking up at the management.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I appreciate the chance you're giving me, Mr. Cromwell, as the single largest stockholder in Teldar, to speak. (gets some laughter and applause, loosens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the way here today I saw a bumper sticker. It said, "Life is a bitch... then you die". (gets another laugh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...well ladies and gentlemen, we're not here to indulge in fantasies, but in political and economic reality. America has become a second rate power. Our trade deficit and fiscal deficit are at nightmare proportions. In the days of the 'free market' when our country was a top industrial power, there was accountability to the shareholders. The Carnegies, the Mellons, the man who built this industrial empire, made sure of it because it was their money at stake. Today management has no stake in the company. Altogether these guys sitting up there own a total of less than 3% and where does Mr. Cromwell put his million dollar salary? Certainly not in Teldar stock, he owns less than 1%. You own Teldar Paper, the stockholders, and you are being royally screwed over by these bureaucrats with their steak lunches, golf and hunting trips, corporate jets, and golden parachutes! Teldar Paper has 33 different vice presidents each earning over $200,000 a year. I spent two months analyzing what these guys did and I still can't figure it out. (a big laugh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cromwell is pissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is an outrage Gekko! You're full of shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thing I do know is this paper company lost $110 million last year, and I'd bet half of that is in the paperwork going back and forth between all the vice presidents... (increased laughter, he's getting them)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The new law of evolution in corporate America seems to be 'survival of the unfittest'. Well in my book, you either do it right or you get eliminated. Teldar Paper is doomed to fail. Its diversification into casualty insurance has not worked. Its crown jewels are its trees, the rest is dross. Through wars, depressions, inflations and deterioration of paper money, trees have always kept their value, but Teldar is chopping them all down. Forests are perishable, forest rights are as important as human rights to this planet, and all the illusory Maginot lines, scorched earth tactics, proxy fights, poison pills, etc. that Mr. Cromwell is going to come up with to prevent people like me from buying Teldar Paper are doomed to fail because the bottom line, ladies and gentlemen, as you very well know, is the only way to stay strong is to create value, that's why you buy stock, to have it go up. If there's any other reason, I've never hear it. (laughter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all I'm saying...it's you people who own this company, not them, they work for you and they've done a lousy job of it. Get rid of them fast, before you all get sick and die. I may be an opportunist, but if these clowns did a better job, I'd be out of work. In the last seven deals I've been in, there were 2.3 million stockholders that actually made a pretax profit of $12 billion. When I bought the Ixtlan Corporation it was in the exact same position Teldar is today -- I turned three of its companies private and I sold four others -- and each of these companies, liberated from the suffering conglomerate has prospered. I am not a destroyer of companies, I am a liberator of them. The point is, ladies and gentlemen, greed is good. Greed works, greed is right. Greed clarifies, cuts through, and captures the essence of the evolutionary spirit. Greed in all its forms, greed for life, money, love, knowledge, has marked the upward surge of mankind -- and greed, mark my words -- will save not only Teldar Paper but that other malfunctioning corporation called the USA...Thank you. Much applause as he sits. Now a standing ovation; shouts approval. Cromwell knows he has lost the day, tries to continue the meeting by calling for "order". Bud watches, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROKERS mill at their desks quietly. Bud enters, notices immediately the uneasy silence. His eyes go to Lynch's office... across the windows, he's talking to a very somb Dan Steeples.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking in the same direction)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynch is giving him the boot... He's not pulling his quota. Bud's soft "no" matched by that second, tighter look. His POV -- closer on the glass... Dan Steeples pleading for h job... we know the things he's saying, we've heard them before... just one more chance, Mr. Lynch... Lynch shakin his head...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reminding him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...we're all just one trade away from humility, Buddy... Dan Steeples steps out of the office, obviously close to tears but trying to maintain face... Buddy's eyes dart aw not wanting to deal with it. Dan Steeples walks by his as Lynch, on the loudspeaker, starts his morning announcemen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New research report on GM and a conference call on defense stocks at my office at 11. No RSVP required, just be there. And on an inspiring note I'm pleased to announce the new office record for a single month's gross commission goes to Bud Fox. Who more than doubled the old mark. Way to go Bud. Super job! Come on up here. As Dan Rickey passes him during this, Bud catches a glimp of the older man's eyes. Dan tries to look brave. Heads turning to Bud with awe and envy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congrats buddy buddy, you just made my life twice as hard around here... Bud moving toward Lynch, past Lou Mannheim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're on a roll kiddo. Enjoy it while it lasts -- 'cause it never does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cocky)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...just kickin' ass and taking names, Mr. Mannheim. Bud passes Charlie Cushing, yawning on the phone as usual

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So whaddaya say pal, wanna play some doubles at Piping? Meet the membership? I got a little blonde named Mandy, about nineteen, avec cafe au lait boobs... she's mine but she's got a cousin who has great muffins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...sounds dubious Chuck, but Piping Rock any day. Chuck laughs, Bud's "in" now. Lynch indicates for Bud to follow him into an outer glass-enclosed office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, Bud...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neatly furnished, with a window overlooking Wall Street, attractive CHINESE SECRETARY filing papers into a cabinet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations. This is yours now... your own file cabinets... a window ... your private secretary, Janet, (under his breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: significantly more attractive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Mr. Fox. She smiles at Bud, who heaves a sigh of relief, noticing name plate on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thrilled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Janet...thank you, Mr. Lynch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you. I knew the minute I laid eyes on you, you had what it takes Bud. Just keep it going. He winks and leaves. Charlie Cushing comes in, Marv stick his head in the doorway, a grudging smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, its Mister Fox now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A splendid four-room thirtieth floor aerie overlooking Central Park. SYLVIE DRIMMER, anchored down with jewelry a large fur purse, shows Bud around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...everybody tells ya they hate the Upper East Side and they wanna live on the West Side but honey when it comes to resale time, believe me the East Side's the one that always moves. What do you get on the West Side? (contemptuously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madonna and Sean?... between Sly and Billy and Christie, I've shown every apartment on the Upper East Side. Everybody lives here... Mick, Gloria and Barbara Wa-Wa. Even Klaus von Bulow buys his fresh fruit from the Korean on Madison. It's so expensive and it's just like the ones on Eighth Avenue but it's an attitude is all, you pay for attitude (pointing to a walk- in closet)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...two walk-in closets...upstairs on the roof you lot a health club...massage, sauna, jacuzzi, sunlights, best schools in the city, cute boy like you gotta think of a ladyfriend when you're finished wolfing around -- ('course I'm taken)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...oak strip floor...my husband can get you a 10% mortgage...I'd do it myself if we weren't into four other deals already...so?... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a four o'clock and a five...one of them's an all-cash type, Monique something or other...I guarantee you this place is history tomorrow... Bud looks around. The city at his feet. Lost in thought. Sylvie has to call him out of it: "honey? -- The meter's running. Anybody home?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Offer 950... Sylvie tries to play it cool, her expression conveying a somewhat stunned look at the speed and certainty of the response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I think you gotta deal, honey... you sure you don't wanna see somethin' I got on Sutton Place. It's a million and a half but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah...this is it..home... Looking it over, proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music is geared to speed, money, triumph and just pla material fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In its first stage, Darien supervising. It's expanse of white walls devoid of mouldings, a blank plaster canvas. city views are great, the apartment identical to hundreds other cookie cutter condos. Several young artists are working on a neo-classical mural on the long side of the living room. They are colorfully dressed, listening to a TALKING HEADS tape while they work. A carpenter who looks like a member of Duran Duran is installing a pair of old columns from Urban Archaeology on either side of the entrance to the living room while another fits a brass si into an antique sideboard which has been turned into a ba

dialogues.speaker: SECOND STAGE
dialogues.text: Living room furniture arrives. A fantail shrimp chaise fr Art Furniture's "Sushi Collection" arrives, along with an enormous sofa encased in an ecru linen slipcover made deliberately baggy and tied on with rows of self bows on each end, several faux Etruscan pots wired up as lamps, a poured concrete coffee table that looks like it came from Pompeii, and a hand-painted floor cloth instead of a rug the bleached floor with the stencilled border... Darien sitting in a fantastical adirondack chair made from gnarl branches, amused by Bud's reactions to the furniture. THIRD STAGE. The kitchen has the latest compact computer dishwasher and compact microwave, garbage compactor, and sinks with infrared controls... A brief food montage give us a sense of the modernist approach to food and its preparation: 1) Darien hones the knives on the electric knife sharpene 2) Bud uses a stainless steel Cape Cod oyster opener to w on two dozen oysters... 3) at the same time working on the automatic vinaigrette mixer, the phone ringing to the tune of Mozart's "Jupiter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking it up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...no...at 37 1/2. Convert the bonds right...and check the price in Tokyo at 8:00 LA time. Thanks... 4) As he starts his pasta sauce flame an his O'Reilly fat free grill with a flexible neck fire starter... 5) A freshly heated roll pops out of a hanging space-savi toaster, as Darien works the electric pasta maker while melting the frozen ice cream cartons in the microwave. 6) Bud manages to sneak a kiss an her lips humming the ba from Verdi's "Rigoletto" as he works the piece de la resistance--the automatic sushi maker... 7) Dinner is finally served on a demolished dinner table. Red wine, pasta, sushi...it looks perfect, lit by candlelight, the view of the city below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...isn't it perfect!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...too perfect...let's not even eat. Let's just watch it and think about it. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: FOURTH STAGE
dialogues.text: Bud goes over a stack of bills with something approaching concern as the gothic oak refectory table which seats 20 carried in, followed by a Jean Michel Basquiat featuring skull on a rough board. Darien instructs the movers to pl an important pair of satinwood Art Deco armchairs upholst in buttery suede (last Saturday's auction purchase for $20,000) at either end of the titanic sofa. No vestige is left of the cookie cutter space we first saw. Walls have been removed, mouldings and architectural found objects added, imitation rare woods, marbles and frescos have bee created from nothing by the magic hands of the tromp l'oe crew. The point is, decorating can transform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The look of the place is evocative of ancient times, yet sumptuous. Darien and Bud sink into the bales of down in sofa and are dwarfed. She rests her head on a hand stenci velvet Venetian throw pillow, looking like a Pre-Raphaeli madonna. A terracotta pot with a spray of white phaleonop graces the coffee table. As the sun sets over the canyons highrises, Bud walks around his new home totally in awe. This apartment, perfect in its restrained taste with all "correct" flowers and objects, has nothing to do with him Perhaps he can understand the state-of-the-art kitchen, t computerized telephone, stereo and light system, but he needs a set of instructions just to be able to switch on David Letterman. This apartment is Darien's fantasy, and Bud is merely the incidental client who paid for it. Most importantly to he it is ready to be photographed by House and Garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dubiously looking at a rough plaster wall of fading fresco)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, the elevator man couldn't believe I paid $300,000 to have my walls looking like this, he's got them for free in Brooklyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet he's got an opinion on the stock market too. This apartment is already ahead of its time. I call it the "demolished" look. They've already heard about it at House and Garden and they're coming next week to photograph it before it gets... lived in. Is that alright? I'd love to have it in my portfolio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure... But your fee... considering you're way over budget, should be negotiable. As he nuzzles her neck, she feels threatened, stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get things straight, Bud. I'm not going to take a cut. I worked hard and you can't decorate a room in New York for less than $100,000. Curtains alone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm kidding, I'm kidding, we're still young, Darien. So what's money anyway when everybody's making it, it's all relative. After all, this is not the house in Connecticut, this is just a crash pad good for a couple of years...before we slip our two lovely kids, Yuppie and Fruppie into the Lycee Francaise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it all charted out don't you, like a stock projection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right -- one with high yield, rich assets and no downside... As the kiss grows, his hands move into her nether regions She looks at him, sober.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think you're ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not me I'm worried about...You know Darien, the only reason we haven't slept together is because we both know we will -- and not knowing when was the only surprise left. You owe me, I want you, what else is there...but you, me, the world. (he folds back her palms in his)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...right here...make love to me...now... (more kissing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop me if I'm going too far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll let you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud making love to Darien. Camara closing on them. Her face -- from his point of view. Her smile. His face -- looking down. Covered with sweat and passion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this real? Is this really real?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud walks out alone in his blue bathrobe on his parapet overlooking Central Park. The wind stirs his hair. The Ea and West sides of the park wrap the city in a diamond necklace of brilliant light. Bud stares down at the world. He has it all now. The mone The girl. The magic palace apartment. What more is there? Something...because Bud suddenly throws a wrenching dislocated look into himself that makes us wonder as he brushes his hand across his face and mutters to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who am I? There is no ready answer. As he finally turns and goes ba inside and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darien lies curled in the bed, eyes open, looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come to bed, Bud...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cocktail hour in the background, yuppies trying to score the weekend. Bud on the phone, strained look transforming a bright, upbeat personality as the phone is answered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dixon! It's your lucky day! That's right. I want to give you some stock and you don't have to put up a penny...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small cabin in the mountains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whole earth furnishings. DIXON, a long-haired ski bum dropout listens skeptically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, and I'm never gonna die either, is this one of your chain letter schemes or do I gotta buy a door to door cosmetic franchise in Northern Arkansas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no Dixon, my client wants to buy a large, large block of stock and needs to spread it around. I'll park some money in your account and if it hits, you get a big cut. I'm telling you, this is the easiest money you ever made...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger listens on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and you don't have to put up a dime, Roger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tentatively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Bud... let's do it. A look on his face. As if he knows he's making a fatal mi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...it's easy Jack! On settlement day, you endorse a check to Blue Horseshoe Trading Company. Then I send you your cut. Marv waves across the glass partition and knocks. But Bud waves him off, closing the blinds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...that's the bottom line. And nobody gets hurt. Marv now walks it, exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...things are so bad, even the liars are complaining. And you're making money. So what gives? What's the bottom line? As he tries to peak at Bud's quotron screen, but Bud flic it off, pissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm tired of playing nurse to you all the time, alright. Do your own home work! Marvin abruptly walks out, "asshole!". Bud books the orde for Morning Star Corp -- MSC -- 50,000 June options.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The COMPANY FLOOR MANAGER gets Bud's order, hands a ticke to a RUNNER who dashes off across the exchange floor, and over to a TRADER who starts to execute the order. CLOSE on the broad tape. As Bud's large buy order flicker across it -- MSC -- 50,000 June options.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A CLERK sits before a computer routinely tracking all of exchange floor trading. He runs a check on a transaction. Computer Screen -- The same numbers and letters are seen that just flickered across the broad tape... Bud's buy. The clerk swivels his chair to a second computer and punc up data. A MAN appears behind him, leaning over his shoulder, and wears an ID BADGE. The clerk vacates his se to the man with the badge, who now takes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud is in silk boxers on the phone, number crunching on t computer, foot pounding to a music beat on the stereo, wh his telex spews out overnight currency data. Darien in the background lies in bed in panties reading V

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buy me 20 June Euro Dollar CDs. Twenty March gold and sell 10 September Deutsch marks. That's right... He hangs up, back to the computer a growing look of excitement and revelation in his eyes. On the computer screen we see a break up Of Bluestar Airlines -- its assets and liabilities. Bud hits the command key, printing it out. He's exuberant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud, I hate to tell you this but you're a genius! (to Darien)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darien...lightning has struck! The lightbulb has been invented. Edison, Da Vinci, Einstein are watching...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grumpy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...are you going to trade all night again? You got to go to work in a couple of hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm gonna broker the rest of my life... I'm going to be a giant, Darien, an entrepreneur in the Italian 15th century sense of the word -- a mover, shaker. Bud dances over to the bed turning the stereo down on his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, baby. Did I tell you that sometime in the last 24 hours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in bed. Y'ever hear of the sixty hour work week? You're turning into a yuppie Frankenstein, you love money so much. Bud grabs a bottle of Ferrier off the night table and dri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, why not, money's the sex of the 80's. I never had it like you when I was growing up, baby, it wasn't the upper east side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're so naive Bud, you don't even know. Your dad took care of you. I might've been rich when I was a kid...but my father lost all his money...in the seventies, in the stock market, at the track. He was a lousy gambler...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teasing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...that changes all my plans, I thought you were loaded...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs woefully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So did I, till I hit 19 and found I had all the royal habits and no throne. Mom got by but I had to go to work just like you. Only the skills I had were shopping and making friends. So...that's why I do what I do, what makes you tick, Buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fear. The fear of being poor I guess, just like you, Darien... But that's all gonna change sweetheart. I'm catching the express... (making love to her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and you're going along for the ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A salon interior. Gekko on a couch reading, with eyeglass a stack of financial reports. Alex is on the phone, Susan and others accompanying the caravan on a business trip. B is excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Bluestar's an unpolished gem, Gordon, right out of the garbage. A half assed management being decimated by a price war they can't win. But the gates at LaGuardia alone can bail us out, it's worth 25 bucks a share if it's worth a dime! They're ripe to fall. Gekko, the poker player, hasn't seen enough cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mixed emotions, Buddy: like Larry Wildman going off a cliff in my new Maserati. Men as smart as myself have got their asses handed to them on a sling with the airlines, fuel could go up, unions are killers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah aren't you forgetting something Gordon: rule one, capital reserves. This company has $75 million cash in an overfunded pension. That buys us a lot of credibility... (Gordon looks up, interested)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and the beauty is you already own close to two percent of this sucker...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting, on the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon, the insurance people are balking on the logging trucks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell those spineless toads we'll self-insure if they don't write it... You fire 33 vice presidents and nothing changes... (back to Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You eating twinkies today, Bud, or are you schtupping some stewardess...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadly serious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon what I want--and I never asked you for anything--is to be your co-pilot on this. I want to take this airline, turn it around, and make it work. It's gonna make us a fortune!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Susan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking to a stockbroker who wants to run an airline. It's gonna take me two years and 2000 headaches to turn Teldar Paper around, what do I need this dink airline for? I'm up to my ass in more nuts than a fruitcake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon, I worked at Bluestar, I know my way around, I have friends there...inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting the drift)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playing out his ace)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three unions. It's 43% of Bluestar's operating budget, the hourly cost of a flight crew is $850 an hour, that's the real hidden value G.G., if you can negotiate that out, get a crew down to $350-400 an hour a run, this airline is gonna be the hottest thing since Texas Air...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you think you can?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can talk to these people Gordon, they trust me...and my father can be a big help in getting cuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright... Susan, get Buckingham on the box. I want him to look at it. And tell Jock Taylor at Thwick, Jensen... (smiles wickedly, back to Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So sport, the falcon has heard the falconer...tell me more...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud, in high gear, all smiles, expensive Armani suit, ope the door. His father stands before him, looking like a ma on his way to the dentist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, well come on in. Everybody's here. We couldn't start the show without you. Wide-eyed, Carl follows Bud through the foyer, taking in furnishings, paintings, antiques.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'll be a lousy Republican.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overhears him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I decorate for Democrats too, lots of them. (she extends her hand and gives him a warm smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Darien Taylor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sardonically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. You're one of the art works that go with the apartment. (softens a little)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty creative. Doesn't look anything like the place my son bought a few months age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I hope you'll come here often, and under less formal circumstances. Halfway won over Carl enters the living room where Darien has set up a table with miniature gourmet pizza, etc. The atmosphere is strained, the camps separated. Gekko stands the bar, conferring with his lawyer, Harold Salt. Darien walks over to the couch with drinks for the Ixtax Union Reps: DUNCAN WILMORE, ALPA Leader, a rugged silver-haired uniformed pilot; TONI CARPENTER, AFA Rep, hard looking, 40ish flight attendant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, you know Duncan Wilmore, pilot's union, and Toni Carpenter, flight attendants...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I met them before you were born. They exchange nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'd like to introduce you to Mr. Gekko, and his lawyer, Mr. Salt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pleasure to meet you, Mr. Fox. Carl stares at Gekko, sizing him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be proud to have a son like Bud. He's got a great future ahead of him. Carl looks to his fellow union representatives, then to G

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing at Salt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought this was an informal meeting. What's he doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismissing him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold, you don't mind strolling around the block a couple hundred times, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at his watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course... Salt gathers his jacket to leave, as Gekko and Carl eye o another, tentatively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...please help yourselves to some food...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The food is half consumed. Gekko addresses the union lead

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I have no illusions about winning a popularity contest with any of you. I was roasted the other night, and a friend of mine asked-- why are we honoring this man--have we run out of human beings? His joke breaks the ice; they laugh, except for Carl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not always the most popular guy who gets the job done. You got losses of 20 to 30 million dollars, dividends cut to zero, you're getting squeezed to death by the majors. Present management may not be the worst scum of the earth, but they're the ones who've put you on a kamikaze course, and pretty soon everybody's going to be scrambling for the parachutes. Only there aren't enough to go around. Management has them. You don't. If they throw Bluestar into Chapter 11--which I think they will--then they can use bankruptcy laws to break your unions and your contracts and throw you guys off the property. We hear a loud crunching sound as Bud's father bites into roll, glaring at Gekko.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pilot)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all due respect, Mr. Gekko, what's to prevent you from doing the same thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause I have a way around all this, a way we can all make money and make this airline profitable again. What do you say we cut to the chase. I'm asking for a modest twenty percent across-the-board wage cut. Carl drops his fork on the plate. Gekko goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And seven more hours a month. Toni Carpenter and Duncan Wilmore exchange questionable l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of time frame are we talking about here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a year. If we're still losing money, the reductions stand. If however, we move into the black, I return part of the givebacks, salaries go back to present levels, and... (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: we institute an employee profit sharing program with stock. You'll own part of the airline. Carpenter and Wilmore react with surprise, it's obvious t weren't expecting the profit sharing part. Bud smiles at Darien and looks to his father, who examines a sushi roll before putting it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you prepared to put that in writing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have a letter of agreement drawn up within two days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
